posts.body:
Boudica

A warrior-queen and folk-hero, Boudica (?-60 or 61 CE) led the Brittonic Iceni tribe in an uprising against the Roman Empire, burning the city that is now London.

[Boadicea Haranguing the Britons, by John Opie]

Her name derives from the Proto-Celtic feminine adjective *boudīkā meaning ‘victorious’. Described as tall, with light brown hair and a piercing glare, Boudica (or Boudicca, or Boadicea, or Buddug, or Bunduca, or Voadicia, or other variants) was the wife of King Prasutagus of the Iceni and a mother to two daughters.

Prasutagus had kept his people free by allying to Rome, but upon his death, the Romans annexed his kingdom and enslaved his people. In response, Boudica rallied her allies and led a military campaign to expel the invaders.

Boudica led her own people, the Iceni, and other groups including the Trinovantes to open revolt. They. destroyed the city of Camulodunum (now Colchester) and Londinium (now London) before burning Verulamium (now an archaeological site near St Albans).

[Boadicea and Her Daughters by Thomas Thornycroft]

The Roman Suetonius had been fleeing the cities as they were destroyed, but rallied and regrouped. He at last defeated Boudica and her army, but she had put up one of the most impressive defences to the imperial Romans the world had ever seen.

Rather than surrender to the enemy, Boudica poisoned herself in a final act of defiance.

On This Day In History

August 23rd, 1970 the Salad Bowl strike, the largest farm worker strike in U.S. history, begins. It is organized by Mexican-American labor union leader César Chávez.

posts.body:
Ahilyabai Holkar, the Indian Philosopher-Warrior-Queen

Ahilyabai Holkar (1725-1795) was an Indian noblewoman during the Maratha Empire who took an active role in the governing of her land, went into battle, and helped promote Hinduism in her people. Her fame was so great she is now spoken about as a near-legendary figure, but her story is well-attested and true.

[a statue of Ahilyabai Holkar]

Born in Chaundi in what is now Western India. She learned to read and write from her father, as women could not go to school. She was married at the age of 10 (and her husband was 12), and gave birth at age 20. She led armies against invaders and captured enemy forts on elephant-back. Her husband died in warfare, and Holkar had resolved to perform sati (ritual suicide via self-immolation), but was convinced not to.

Her son became regent but also died quickly. Still in mourning for her husband and her child, Holkar took up rulership of Indore. Some objected, but she had the support of the army and of the people.

[the Kashi Vishwanath Temple, c. 1915]

Holkar was a renowned stateswoman and military leader. The city of Indore flourished and she met with the public daily. She improved public infrastructure, sponsored festivals, and built and supported dozens of wells, rest-houses, and temples, most notably the Kashi VIshwanath Temple. She was notably lax with taxes and merchants and farmers were about to accumulate wealth and stability. She supported artisans and poets, and established a textile industry in the city of Maheshwar.

[Ahilyabai Holkar honored on a stamp]

She died at age 70, having lived a good and full life after the passing of her husband. Her rule was called a golden age and she is remembered as a fair ruler who spread peace, but could also defend her people. She is a pseudo-legendary figure (pseudo only because, as far as I can tell, everything people say is 100% true). An award in her name is given annually to outstanding public figures.

posts.body:
Paracas Mantle (1250-1BCE) Paracas culture on the southern coast of Peru. Textile.

Currently on display at the Museo Larco in Lima, Peru.

Image description: four photographs of an old textile on a black background. The textile is brown, tan, black, and blue, with a fringe. The designs are geometric depictions of animals–smiling cats with snake bodies and bird feet.

posts.summary: Maggie Kuhn and the Gray Panthers
posts.body:
Maggie Kuhn and the Gray Panthers

August, 21st is World Senior Citizen’s Day! Let’s take some time to acknowledge one of the big names in elder rights activism.

“Put your body on the line. Stand before the people you fear and speak your mind – even if your voice shakes.” -Maggie Kuhn

[Kuhn]

Maggie Kuhn (1905-1995) was an American activist from Buffalo, New York who worked in feminism, disability rights, desegregation, poverty reduction, sexual education, and opposition to war. She’s most known for founding the Gray Panthers, a multi-generational advocacy network.

She began her activist history at age 25 working at the YWCA (the now-defunct woman’s equivalent to YMCA community centers). She educated women about unionizing and started a human sexuality class that was incredibly controversial.

[Kuhn in 1953]

Throughout World War II, she advocated against the war (though she did become program director for the YWCA-USO). She advocated for desegregation, urban housing, against McCarthyism, and against nuclear proliferation.

In the 1950s and 1960s, she worked for the Presbyterian Church, but drew on the philosophy of her Jewish background. She insisted all her students much work with the impoverished in the local community, not just churchgoers. In 1961, she began to be concerned about elder rights, which she visited retirement homes that she described as ‘glorified playpens’.

Nearly all of her activist work had been through her various jobs, in which she was incredibly active. But in 1970, that all came to an end. Kuhn turned 65 and was forced to retire. Disliking this, she and other retirees formed the Gray Panthers movement (named after the Black Panthers, the radical African-American rights organization).

[the logo and motto of the Gray Panthers]

Like the Black Panthers, the Gray Panthers focused on their social ill of choice but considered all justice issues linked and did not restrict themselves to pure ageism. Many of its members were high school and college students because Kuhn believed in expanding rights in all marginalized age groups. She considered the lack of trust society placed in both the elderly and teenagers a result of an exploitative society that didn’t value lives that couldn’t work.

The Gray Panthers successfully got banks to help the elderly by financially independent, openly discussed the sexuality of older people (and said that older women, who tend to outlive their husbands, might develop sexual and romantic relationships with each other, an incredibly unpopular statement at the time), fought against the medical administration that perpetuated the illusion of the elderly as incapacitated, and called into question the representation of old people in popular media.

The Gray Panthers also fought against “disengagement theory”, which said that the elderly should be separated from the rest of society as a prelude to death. Kuhn founded the Shared Housing Resources Center, which helps younger adults live with retirees in a way that is mutually beneficial–a practice that is becoming increasingly popular.

Beyond pure ageism, Kuhn and the Gray Panthers vocally opposed the Vietnam War and accusing politicians of creating an intergenerational war as a smokescreen to distract from real fiscal issues with military overspending and extravagant tax breaks for the rich. Kuhn died at age 89, 24 years after society said she no longer had anything to contribute to it, having changed the world.

[Kuhn]

In recent years and today, the Gray Panthers have continued to fight. They are engaged in anti-war activism, Medicare and Social Security preservation, LGBT+ rights, environmentalism, single-payer healthcare, fair treatment in nursing homes, prioritizing elder healthcare during the COVID-19 pandemic, and racial justice.

Check out the Gray Panthers here

Nearly all of her activist work had been through her various jobs, in which she was incredibly active. But in 1970, that all came to an end. Kuhn turned 65 and was forced to retire. Disliking this, she and other retirees formed the Gray Panthers movement (named after the Black Panthers, the radical African-American rights organization).

[the logo and motto of the Gray Panthers]

Like the Black Panthers, the Gray Panthers focused on their social ill of choice but considered all justice issues linked and did not restrict themselves to pure ageism. Many of its members were high school and college students because Kuhn believed in expanding rights in all marginalized age groups. She considered the lack of trust society placed in both the elderly and teenagers a result of an exploitative society that didn’t value lives that couldn’t work.

The Gray Panthers successfully got banks to help the elderly by financially independent, openly discussed the sexuality of older people (and said that older women, who tend to outlive their husbands, might develop sexual and romantic relationships with each other, an incredibly unpopular statement at the time), fought against the medical administration that perpetuated the illusion of the elderly as incapacitated, and called into question the representation of old people in popular media.

The Gray Panthers also fought against “disengagement theory”, which said that the elderly should be separated from the rest of society as a prelude to death. Kuhn founded the Shared Housing Resources Center, which helps younger adults live with retirees in a way that is mutually beneficial–a practice that is becoming increasingly popular.

Beyond pure ageism, Kuhn and the Gray Panthers vocally opposed the Vietnam War and accusing politicians of creating an intergenerational war as a smokescreen to distract from real fiscal issues with military overspending and extravagant tax breaks for the rich. Kuhn died at age 89, 24 years after society said she no longer had anything to contribute to it, having changed the world.

[Kuhn]

In recent years and today, the Gray Panthers have continued to fight. They are engaged in anti-war activism, Medicare and Social Security preservation, LGBT+ rights, environmentalism, single-payer healthcare, fair treatment in nursing homes, prioritizing elder healthcare during the COVID-19 pandemic, and racial justice.

Check out the Gray Panthers here

Maggie Kuhn and the Gray Panthers

August, 21st is World Senior Citizen’s Day! Let’s take some time to acknowledge one of the big names in elder rights activism.

“Put your body on the line. Stand before the people you fear and speak your mind – even if your voice shakes.” -Maggie Kuhn

[Kuhn]

Maggie Kuhn (1905-1995) was an American activist from Buffalo, New York who worked in feminism, disability rights, desegregation, poverty reduction, sexual education, and opposition to war. She’s most known for founding the Gray Panthers, a multi-generational advocacy network.

She began her activist history at age 25 working at the YWCA (the now-defunct woman’s equivalent to YMCA community centers). She educated women about unionizing and started a human sexuality class that was incredibly controversial.

[Kuhn in 1953]

Throughout World War II, she advocated against the war (though she did become program director for the YWCA-USO). She advocated for desegregation, urban housing, against McCarthyism, and against nuclear proliferation.

In the 1950s and 1960s, she worked for the Presbyterian Church, but drew on the philosophy of her Jewish background. She insisted all her students much work with the impoverished in the local community, not just churchgoers. In 1961, she began to be concerned about elder rights, which she visited retirement homes that she described as ‘glorified playpens’.

posts.body:
Sir Ewan Forbes, 11th Baronet

A trans intersex man, Sir Ewan Forbes of Craigievar (1912-1991) was a Scottish nobleman who successfully argued for and received his legal rights.

[Ewan in 1952]

Born to a well-established Scottish nobleman who held both a barony and a baronetcy (baronets are just below barons and the hierarchy of nobility), Ewan was the youngest of four children. Assigned female at birth, and raised as such, Ewan’s childhood has a well-documented history of dysphoria. He mostly played with other boys and dressed in boy’s clothes, and often skipped social engagements entirely rather than wear a dress to them. Ewan also refused to attend a girls’ school, and so was educated at home.

A well-educated man, Ewan spoke multiple languages including Doric, attended the Sorbonne in Paris, and was an accomplished public reciter and harpist. He studied medicine in Munich, self-funded, but left when his older brother inherited the barony and baronetcy, and Ewan himself inherited a lairdship.

In 1944, he graduated from medical school at the University of Aberdeen, where he worked in the Aberdeen Royal Infirmary and acted as a medical officer for German prisoners of war from World War II (he had left Munich slightly after the Nazis were elected into power) due to his fluency in German.

In 1952, he legally transitioned and changed his gender on his warrant for birth, which he publically announced in the newspaper. His patients, family, and friends all knew about his transition and were described as ‘universally supportive’. That same year, he married a woman, Isabella Mitchell, his housekeeper/dance partner.

His life continued normally until 1965, when his older brother died with no sons. The baronry passed to a daughter, but the law of the land meant the baronetcy (and most of the land) was to pass to the first male heir. It was the will of nearly the entire family that Ewan should be so, but his cousin challenged him.

John Forbes-Sempill would receive the baronetcy if Ewan was considered an invalid heir. The case was taken to court–but kept rather secret. We know that 12 separate medical experts were called in, with some disagreement, but the judge ultimately ruled in favor of Ewan (some suggest he simply believe Ewan was a better candidate). This was appealed, but the decision was upheld and Ewan was confirmed as the rightful holder of the title.

Ewan Forbes was an accomplished linguist, artist, physician, and lord who was intersex and transitioned. He was accepted by his family, community, and wife with full knowledge and without hesitation, and lived a full life.

posts.body:
Black Caesar

Black Caesar (?-1718) was a pirate active in the Caribbean during the Golden Age of Piracy. One of the most notable Black pirates (though modern estimates suggest fully one-third of pirates in this time period were Black so he certainly wasn’t the only one), he was a leader of men, served on the Queen Anne’s Revenge with Blackbeard, and escaped the ship that had enslaved him from Africa, leaving his slavers to drown in a hurricane.

A political leader in West Africa, Caesar was tricked onto a ‘merchant’ ship that raised anchor and sailed away. Caesar befriended a single man working on the ship. As they neared Florida and prepared to be sold in the slave markets, a hurricane hit. That sailor broke Caesar out of the hold and, together, forced the other workers belowdecks and stole a longboat and supplies. They made it to shore, and the slaver ship sunk with everyone else still inside.

Using an island north of Key Large (now referred to as Caesar’s Rock) as his headquarters, Caesar spent ten years pirating and growing his crew, amassing a large amount of treasure and evading the law.

After a decade, Caesar joined Blackbeard’s army as a Lieutenant on the flagship, the Queen Anne’s Revenge–a great honor. During a raid, he was captured, convicted of piracy, and hanged. This in and of itself was unusual–hanging was often reserved for White pirates, while Black pirates were sold.

Piracy was actually a relatively progressive tradition–it had worker’s rights, disability rights, democracy voting traditions, and a surprising amount of active and successful Black people and women for the time period. Black Caesar is just one example of this.

posts.body:
Chevalier d’Éon

A French diplomat, spy, and solider, Chevalier d’Éon (1728-1810) who lived life as both a man and a woman.

[d’Éon in half and half clothes]

Born into a poor noble family, d’Éon excelled in school, especially law and politics, and quickly became part of the political bureaucracy of the Kingdom of France. In 1756, d’Éon became a spy as was sent to the Russian Empire, serving for four years in the Empress’s house without being caught. Later, d’Éon served in the Seven Years’ War as a captain of dragoons and helped draft the Treaty of Paris that ended said war.

[d’Éon presenting as a man]

After the war, d’Éon was demoted to secretary in England (still working as a spy), and claimed the new ambassador, Guerchy, had attempted murder. d’Éon release some classified documents, but cleverly not all, so the French government was cautious in dealing with this betrayal. Though d’Éon lost the case and was declared an outlaw in France, the British firm grew to hate ambassador Guerchy.

After the death ofKing Louis XV in 1774, d’Éon successfully negotiated a return to France and began living as a woman. d’Éon claimed at this time to be AFAB, but when a good-humor betting pool started, d’Éon declined to have the matter settled, so much of society was uncertain.

[d’Éon presenting as a woman]

Some said that d’Éon was a woman pretending to be a man in order to preserve familial inheritance. Others said that d’Éon was a man pretending to be a woman so the government would be more forgiving. It does not seem that d’Éon was shunned for society despite widespread thought that d’Éon was a crossdress (even if they couldn’t agree on which way).

d’Éon asked the monarchy to be allowed to lead French soldiers to help rebels in the American War of Independence, but was denied. d’Éon lived through the French Revolution, starting in 1789, and became significantly poorer. Here, d’Éon asked the French National Assembly to lead an all-women division of soldiers, and was likewise denied.

[d’Éon presenting as a woman, fencing a man]

posts.body:
Willmer ‘Little Axe’ Broadnax

Willmer Broadnax (1916-1992) was a famous American tenor singer during the golden age of traditional Black gospel music. Called ‘Little Ax’ next to his taller brother, William 'Big Axe’ Broadnax.

Born in Houston, Texas, Broadnax began singing gospel as a teenager. Willmer and William both left for Los Angeles to join the Southern Gospel Singers, before forming their own quarter. When William left to singing in Atlanta, Willmer stayed in his group, Little Axe and the Golden Echoes. Known for his uniquely high singing voice, described by a contemporary as 'sweer but almost vicious, dripping with emotion’.

Willmer continued to move around the south, to Memphis and Mississippi, touring and recording for decades. Even after retirement, he continued to record with the Five Blind Boys of Mississippi into the 1980s.

In 1992, Willmer was killed in a lover’s quarrel. Upon his death, it was announced publically that Willmer was a trans man. While only his family knew for certain, many in the gospel music scene said they knew, guessed, or wondered, and simply didn’t care.

Today, Willmer Broadnax is remembered as a talented Black trans man at the forefront of a vibrant musical tradition.

Songs to Listen To!

1. “When the Saints go Marching In”
2. “You Are My Sunshine”

posts.body:
Karen Ulane

A pilot and an activist, Karen Ulane (1941-1989) sparked a court case that set important legal precedent for gender in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

Born in Chicago, Illinois on December 10th, 1941, Ulane quickly fell in love with flying. She was employed with Eastern Airlines (now defunct) in 1968. In April 1980, she transitioned and changed her legal name.

She was terminated for this and filed discrimation suit. She won the case, but it was overturned on appeal.

Her legal defense also showed the discrimination against all women in aviation, a historically male-dominated profession:

“In terms of sexual discrimination, Karen Ulane was kind of a perfect control group,” said Fay Clayton, one of her lawyers. “As a male pilot, Eastern’s own witnesses acknowledged that she was one of their better pilots. When she changed her sex, she was all of a sudden not acceptable. Eastern was willing to retain one sex in their employ, but not willing to retain the other.” [source]

However, her work was later used when adapting the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to include protections on the basis of gender identity or transgender status. The argument was that discrimination on the basis of gender identity had to be based on ideas about static male/female gender roles, so it needed to be included. Similar arguments were made for sexual orientation!

This inclusion helped extended protections afforded under the Civil Rights Act to trans people, like prohibitions against employment discrimination. Thanks to Karen Ulane, a brave woman who was unafraid to show her true self to the world and fight for it, the impacts were felt decades later across the country.

posts.body:
Elagabalus

Elagabalus, or Heliogabalus, (203 or 204-222 CE) was the emperor of Roman from 218-222. Reigning under the name Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, was a famously irreverent and controversial leader. He was assassinated at age 18, on orders of Julia Maesa, his own grandmother.


[Elagabalus]

Probably born in Emesa, Syria (now Homs, Syria), he was the high priest of Elagabal, an Arab-Roman sun god. His cousin, Caracalla, was the emperor of Rome, until their shared grandmother had Caracalla assassinated and Elagabalus put in his place. He was immediately beset by multiple mutinies and denouncements by other politicians and spent much of his four years in power trying to quell them. He also replaced Jupiter as head of the Roman pantheon with his own favored Elagabal.

As a young adult for all of his reign, Elagabalus was known for his social life. He threw wild parties on the summer solstice and paraded around town in ostentatious clothes and chariots. He had a number of lovers, both male and female. He was the husband of multiple wives, and was also called the wife to her husband, Hierocles. [note, this is from Cassius Dio, a contemporary statesman whose work is seen as one of the most accurate and reliable representations. Dio occasionally uses feminine pronouns for Elagabalus.]

[the reverse of a coin, showing Elagabalus]

Elagabalus apparently loved being called Hierocles’s mistress, preferred being called ‘lady’ instead of 'lord’, wore makeup and wigs, and loudly requested sex reassignment surgery. He also, notably, allowed women to attend Senate meetings.

Again, Julia Maesa had one of her grandsons assassinated and set up another to take his place.

His cousin, Caracalla, was the emperor of Rome, until their shared grandmother had Caracalla assassinated and Elagabalus put in his place. He was immediately beset by multiple mutinies and denouncements by other politicians and spent much of his four years in power trying to quell them. He also replaced Jupiter as head of the Roman pantheon with his own favored Elagabal.

As a young adult for all of his reign, Elagabalus was known for his social life. He threw wild parties on the summer solstice and paraded around town in ostentatious clothes and chariots. He had a number of lovers, both male and female. He was the husband of multiple wives, and was also called the wife to her husband, Hierocles. [note, this is from Cassius Dio, a contemporary statesman whose work is seen as one of the most accurate and reliable representations. Dio occasionally uses feminine pronouns for Elagabalus.]

[the reverse of a coin, showing Elagabalus]

Elagabalus apparently loved being called Hierocles’s mistress, preferred being called ‘lady’ instead of 'lord’, wore makeup and wigs, and loudly requested sex reassignment surgery. He also, notably, allowed women to attend Senate meetings.

Again, Julia Maesa had one of her grandsons assassinated and set up another to take his place.

posts.body:
Myrna (and Helen) Mack

Myrna Mack Chang (1949-1990) was a Chinese-Mayan anthropologist from Guatemala, and a human rights activist working for indigenous rights. She was assassinated by the government for her outspoken criticisms, and her sister, Helen (1952-) lead the multi-year battle for justice.

[Myrna]

Born in southwest Guatemala to a Chinese mother and Maya father, Myrna studied anthropology abroad in the United Kingdom. Upon her return home, she conducted fieldwork among the Maya communities.

After the Guatemalan Civil War from 1960 to 1996, many indigenous people had been displaced. Working with them, she became an outspoken human rights activist with a focus on indigenous rights.

[Myrna]

She brought international attention to the state-sanction extermination of indigenous people and their large-scale resistance. She also helped uncover and make known the role of U.S. corporations and the U.S. government in allowing this dictatorship and supporting this genocide.

The U.S. government organized, funded, and equipped the 1954 coup that replaced the democratically elected leader of Guatemala, developed Guatemala’s military campaign, and gave training and intelligence throughout the conflict.

She was assassinated for her anti-government remarks outside her office. Her assassins also had ties with and were trained at school from the U.S. government.

In the 36 years of the Guatemalan Civil War, some 200,000 civilians, including Mack, were murdered. 93% of them were Maya. The military carried out 626 massacres against the Maya during the conflict, destroying 440 villages in just two years.

Her younger sister, Helen, along with their mother began to push for legal justice in a process that took over a decade. She pursued the prosecution in the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, resulting in the convictions of an assailant and a high-ranking colonel in the military. In 1993, she established the Myrna Mack Foundation to support the continued prosecution of her sister’s murderers and other human rights work. The Guatemalan government acknowledged responsibility and paid compensation to her family in 2004 and appointed her to lead investigations into police corruption in 2010.

[Helen]

Helen has been the recipient of multiple humans rights and public service awards around the globe.

posts.body:
Marie Laveau

The Voodoo Queen of New Orleans.

[portrait of Laveau, most people who knew her said it looks nothing like her]

Marie Catherine Laveau (1801-1881) was a Voodo practitioner, herbalist, and midwife. Born a free woman of color in French Louisiana, New France. She was a Louisiana Creole, a population group descended from inhabitants of colonial Louisiana before it became part of the U.S. in 1803 that was primarily African, French, Spanish, and Native American. (After the United States took the land, it increasingly became identified with mixed race-ethnic groups.)

Much of her life is uncertain. She was born probably in 1801, though some sources say as much as 5 years earlier. Her mother, Marguerite D'Arcantel, is described as a free woman of color and a former slave. Her father, Charles Trudeau, was a wealthy White man and Laveau was born out of wedlock and raised by her maternal grandmother, an African-born freedwoman and entrepreneur.

She got married in 1819 to Jacques Paris, a free man of color who fled to New Orleans after the Haitian Revolution and who died a year later. Then she moved in with her long-term partner, Christophe Dominick Duminy de Glapion, a Frenchman in what was known as a plaçage marriage, a recognized, extralegal, semi-institutionalized system of interracial “marriage.”

Laveau’s life is one of mystery and self-contradiction. Herself the daughter of a one-time enslaved mother, Laveau own at least seven slaves in her lifetime. She was the Queen of Voodoo and a devout Catholic all her life.

As a Voodoo, Laveau was a healer and herbalist. As its queen, she played a social role in people’s relationships and marriages. She also was an entrepreneur, starting a beauty parlor for wealthy families. It functioned as a social spot and a way for her to collect gossip (and by scaring it out of servants).

[Laveau’s house in New Orleans. today a landmark]

Much about her Voodoo cannot be substantiated–if she ever tried to curse people, if she succeeded, the exact origins of her magical practice. It was likely part Roman Catholic saint-worship mixed with West African religious practices, though some sources suggest she also drew upon Native American spiritualism–as a Creole woman, she may have been partially Native American (the one source I can find that claimed this said Choctaw, but I couldn’t substantiate it anywhere else).

As a community activist, she did rituals for the needy, provided lessons and work to women, and visiting prisoners on death’s row. Most established sources say she went only to perform Catholic traditions, rumors said that she gave them poisons and potions to ease their passing. She also occasionally successful got pardons of some prisoners. She worked as a healer during the recurrent Yellow Fever epidemics and helped finance churches and raise children that were not her own.

She was the third, and most renowned, Queen of Voodoo in New Orleans. After her death, she was celebrated by all parts of the city, though rumor says she has been seen walking around since.

One of her daughters, Marie Laveau II (1827-1862) became the next Queen of Voodoo. She is still recognized as a major figure in Voodoo and venerated in the Folk Catholicism of the region. Her attributes are water and roosters, and she is the patron of mothers, children, fevers, love, and volunteerism.

Her attributes are water and roosters, and she is the patron of mothers, children, fevers, love, and volunteerism.

posts.body:
Carl Linneaus

Carl Linnaeus (1707-1778) was a Swedish botanist from formalised the binomial nomenclature [e.g. Homo sapiens for modern-day humans or Felis catus for domestic cats] used to name organisms and is the Father of Modern Taxonomy (the science of naming and categorizing living things).

[Linnaeus in his late 60s]

Linnaeus was the oldest child of a family of peasants and priests. From a young age, Linnaeus enjoyed plants and tended his own garden plot. His father also taught him Latin, in which Linnaeus would do most of his writing.

His father, incidentally, was the first in their family’s history to have a surname. He chose the name Linnæus, after the linden tree that grew on his family’s land, when he needed a surname to attend university.

His father invested in Linnaeus’ education from a young age, an investment Linnaeus usually spurned. He hated his early tutor and skipped school, so he was put on an apprenticeship track to become a cobbler. Had this happened, our fundamentally understanding of the Earth and its living things would be forever changed.

In what should have been his last year of school, the headmaster noticed and nurtured Linnaeus’ interests in botany and introduce him to academic botanists. For the first time in his life, a fifteen-year-old Linnaeus finally started to study in earnest.

He chose to continue his education on a track often for priests, where he once again performed with mediocrity. Running out of options in academia, Linnaeus began to study physiology and life science with a family friend. He would eventually become a physician.

[his wedding portrait]

Here Linnaeus’ education took off. His thesis on plant sexual reproduction was so excellent that as only a second-year student he began to give lectures to his fellow students, sometimes with an audience of 300 people. He also began to disagree with the Tournefort system of plant classification, then the scientific standard, and started to divide his own.

He became collecting and describing plants and animals, travelling up to remote Lapland for it.

[the twinflower (Linnaea borealis). Named after Linnaeus in his taxonomy, it was his favorite flower]

He continued to travel and then set out to study medicine in the Dutch Republic, at the time a more prestigious country for natural history education. On the way there, Linnaeus managed to get himself and his friend run out of town for correcting a mayor’s alleged taxidermied hydra heads.

He received a doctoral degree in only two weeks (more a sign of the standards of education at the time than of any particular brilliance of his). In 1735, Linnaeus published the Systema Naturae.

[Systema Naturae]

The 1735 Systema Naturae gained him some fame and publicity, but what truly made him famous and changed the world was its 10th edition. Published in two volumes in 1758 and 1759, Linnaeus official introduced the binomial nomenclature for animals. Up until now, he had used it for plants, but using the same system between Kingdoms and Domains is seminal in the shift to modern biology.

The 10th edition was also more complete and more correct (it listed whales and manatees as mammals rather than fish, for example). His divisions into 6 classes of animals were based on internal anatomy, and though it has been heavily revised in the hundreds of years since its introduction, the format remains the same today.

There’s more of his story–his various tutors, teachers, friends, and students (the primary 17 of which he called his ‘Apostles’, whom he helped to take sometimes fatal expeditions plant gathering across the globe), his ennoblement by the Swedish King Adolf Frederick and the almost immediate end of his noble line. But we shall end with this: 1959, Linnaeus was designated the lectotype, the single specimen, which set the standards for the classification of H. sapiens (modern-day humans).

[I can’t come up with a description any better than the one Wikipedia already provides]

[the coat of arms he designed for his house. It didn’t last very long.]

posts.summary: "¿Rendirme yo? ¡Que se rinda su abuela, carajo!"
posts.body:
“¿Rendirme yo? ¡Que se rinda su abuela, carajo!”

Translation from Spanish: “Surrender, me? Your grandmother should surrender, bastard!”

-Abaroa, Eduardo (1838-1879)

Last words of Bolivian civilian resistance leader and later folk hero.

Source: Last Words of Notable People by William B. Brahms

posts.body:
The Pahlavi Crown (1926). Created by Haj Serajeddin Javaheri for Reza Shah Pahlavi. Part of the Iranian Crown Jewels. Gold, silver, red velvet, diamonds, white pearls, emeralds.

Currently on display at the Treasury of National Jewels in Tehran.
